Problem:
Consider a linear system governed by the differential equation \\(\\dot{x} = Dx\\), where D is a diagonalizable matrix. We explore the system's behavior under the influence of the transformation \\( f(x) = S^{-1}e^{Mt}Sx \\), where M is another constant matrix and S is a matrix that diagonalizes D, i.e., \\( SDS^{-1} = \\Lambda \\), with \\( \\Lambda \\) being a diagonal matrix.

If we apply \\( f(x) \\) to an initial vector \\( x_0 \\) at time t = 0 and let the system evolve according to \\(\\dot{x} = Dx\\) without any additional changes, will the vector \\( x(t) \\) at time T be the same as when the system evolves from \\( x_0 \\) without applying \\( f(x) \\) at t = 0?
Explanation: Applying the transformation \\( f(x) \\) at t = 0 modifies the initial condition and thus changes the trajectory. The presence of the matrix exponential \\( e^{Mt} \\) along with the similarity transformation by S means the evolution from the modified initial condition diverges from that of the unmodified \\( x_0 \\), resulting in a different state at time T.
